Award.AwardTitle: Arithmetic on Shimura Varieties and Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
Mathematics has always been essential to the development of science and technology. Now mathematics is becoming increasingly important, too, to business, finance, biology, and social sciences. Basic research in mathematics, which is thought of as "pure" mathematics, is increasingly finding deep applications in unexpected areas. The research area of this project has this flavor. On the one hand, the principal investigator is investigating Shimura varieties, whose definition itself involves both geometry and representation theory. These objects lie at the center of modern number theory. In their simplest cases, the modular curves, they have been studied for more than one hundred years and were essential to the proof of Fermat's Last Theorem, one of the most famous and oldest conjectures in mathematics. On the other hand, the investigator's research results in recent years have become useful in algebraic curve cryptosystems. These are essential to the safety of electronic commerce and communication. The investigator will continue to work on these types of applications.

In one of the projects joint with Bruinier, Howard, Kudla, and Rapoport, the investigator aims to prove that a generating function of arithmetic Chow cycles in the Shimura varieties of unitary type is modular. As an application, he will prove more non-Abelian cases of the Colmez Conjecture. In another project, the investigator will try to understand the L-function side of the Colmez conjecture and obtain clues on how to attack the general case. In yet another project, the investigator will study, with collaborators, CM values of some interesting Borcherds projects. These have two purposes: one is to prove some classical conjectures, and the other is an application to cryptosystems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
It took me 4 years (2015-19) to finish the project `Arithmetic on Shimura Varieties and Applications’. In this project, I continue to gain deeper and deeper understanding on the arithmetic on Shimura varieties and applications.  Shimura varieties are vast generalization of the beautiful classical modular curves, started by Shimura in late 1960s and further developed by Deligne and others in early 1970s. Since then, the geometry, arithmetic, and associated representation properties have been intensively studied and many progress has been made, which  in turn  has raised even more interesting questions.

  My study of Shimura varieties started about 20 years ago when Kudla, Rapoport, and I tried to understand Kudla’s  far reaching ideas and conjectures (now called Kudla program). One first focus is arithmetic Siegel-Weil formula for Shimura curves, which is still the only complete one and resulted a research book (Annals of Math Study 161). This result gave people confidence on possible general theory. After that, Bruinier and I found cool applications of a slightly different Kudla program to generalized Gross-Zagier formulas and also so-called big CM value formula (with Bruinier and Kudla)

  In current project,  I have made many fruitful discoveries. Some are fundamental and others are breakthrough in method. I have 13 published and accepted research papers (2015-19),  including

  1. A joint paper of 95 pages with Bruinier and Howard to prove the first generalization of Gross-Zagier in any dimension (for Shimura variety of unitray type (n-1, 1). It was published in Invent. Math., one of the three most prestigious math journals.
  2. Inspired by the deep formula,  Bruinier, Howard, Kudla, Rapoport, and I spent 3 years to prove a general modularity of some arithmetic generating function of arithmetic divisors on a Shimura variety mentioned in 1. It has already a lot of applications, and resulting two long papers accepted at  Asterisque.
  3. Bruinier and I proved a general Arithmetic Siegel-Weil formula on orthogonal Shimura varieties of type (n, 2).  The methods are also totally new.
  4. Hongbo Yin,  Peng Yu, and I applied my big CM value formula with Bruinier and Kudla to product of modular curves, and proved  quite  few new results on the classical j-function, lambda function, and Weber functions, resulting two papers in Trans AMS and IMRN.
  5. Tuoping Du and I proved an arithmetic Siegel-Weil and a twisted arithmetic Siegel-Weil formula on modular curves, extended my work with  Kudla and Rapoport to this case. Here the tricky part turns out to at cusps. This resulted in 2 papers published in Adv. In Math. and  J. Number Theory.
  6. I also worked on my own and with collaborators on  Colmez conjecture, Borcherds liftings on unitary Shimura varieties, big CM formula applying to genus two curves, and Galois action on CM points, and so on, with 5 publications.

….

During this period, the NSF grant also helped me trained and graduated 4 PhD students, two of them have already tenure track jobs, one has a postdoc position, and one got an industrial job.  I have currently 2 PhD students in training.
